Title.evidence: The EXPELLIARMUS shows that medical students can successfully conduct randomized controlled trials in surgery.

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery were enrolled, equipped with an FT, and randomly assigned to the experimental (visible screen) or control intervention (blackened screen).

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery were enrolled, equipped with an FT, and randomly assigned to the experimental (visible screen) or control intervention (blackened screen).

Intervention.evidence: The experimental group received daily step goals and feedback through the FT.

Objective.evidence: Objective:: To determine whether daily postoperative step goals and feedback through a fitness tracker (FT) reduce the rate of postoperative complications after surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary end point was postoperative morbidity within 30 days using the Comprehensive Complication Index (CCI).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery were enrolled, equipped with an FT, and randomly assigned to the experimental (visible screen) or control intervention (blackened screen).

Blinding.evidence: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery were enrolled, equipped with an FT, and randomly assigned to the experimental (visible screen) or control intervention (blackened screen).

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 347 patients were enrolled.

Number_Analysed.evidence: No imputation for the primary end point was necessary as data completeness was 100%.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no significant difference in the CCI between the 2 groups in the intention-to-treat analysis (mean±SD CCI experimental group: 23±24 vs. control: 22±22; 95% CI: −6.1, 3.7; P =0.628).
